Fall 2018

Several classes that will be offered in Fall 2018 were omitted out of lack of interest.

55—Discrete Math

Instructor(s): Haiman; Offered: Every semester

Haiman is a lot of fun and a wonderful lecturer, but does not respond to emails. This class should be taken before any upper division classes if you don't have any experience writing proofs.

104—Real Analysis

Instructor(s): Lovejoy, Hadfield, Jao, Iliopoulou, Zhu, Bragg, Shimizu, Wodzicki (Honors); Offered: Every semester

Lovejoy is a decent professor with good office hours, and is a safe choice. Hadfield cares about his students, but is more likely to focus on the calculus side of 104 than the topology side. Iliopoulou is a clear instructor with good notes. Shimizu, Zhu, and Bragg are all new to campus. Wodzicki should be avoided, in light of tendency to ramble on after class as late as 2 am (true story).

110—Linear Algebra

Instructor(s): Shin, Harrison (Honors); Offered: Every semester

Shin is approachable and easy to learn from. Harrison will approach the course from a much more abstract perspective than most instructors, including tensor products and category theory, and while she teaches valuable concepts it would be wortwhile to already know abstract algebra before taking her class.

113—Abstract Algebra

Instructor(s): Shende, Vojta, Wodzicki, Shimizu, Corteel, Vaintrob; Offered: Every semester

Shende posts all notes online and is approachable. Vojta is understandable and inserts his own topics, such as impossibility of angle trisection, into the class. Wodzicki should be avoided (see 104 notes). Shimizu, Corteel, and Vaintrob are all new to campus.

125A—Mathematical Logic

Instructor(s): Slaman; Offered: Most semesters

113 is absolutely a necessary prerequisite for this class. Because of department politics, 125B does not exist. Slaman is approachable and will try to answer every question. This class also fulfills the Philosophy and Values breadth.

126—Partial Differential Equations

Instructor(s): Laux; Offered: Most semesters

???

128A—Numerical Analysis

Instructor(s): Wilkening; Offered: Every semester

This is the most computational upper-division class and should be taken before most upper divs. Matlab is easy to learn.

136—Incompleteness and Undecidability

Instructor(s): Slaman; Offered: Most semesters

See 125A for notes on Slaman.

141—Differential Topology

Instructor(s): Givental; Offered: Sometimes

In contrast to typical semesters, Givental will probably cover Stokes' theorem, the Morse-Sard theorem, and advanced topics. This course may be harder than in usual semesters because Givental will not dumb anything down. However, he cares about this field a lot, as it is his research area.

143—Algebraic Geometry

Instructor(s): Tonkonong; Offered: Sometimes

This course is usually taught by a postdoc of Sturmfels, who teaches it with emphasis on computational techniques. This is not the case with Tonkonog, who is more likely to focus on theory.

185—Complex Analysis

Instructor(s): Hadfield, Klass, Laux, Corwin, Artomonov; Offered: Every semester

Hadfield's H185 was quite challenging but he'll probably be more gentle in 185. Laux is a solid choice who will emphasize computation. Artomonov is new to campus.

191—Experimental Courses - Putnam Prep

Instructor(s): Givental; Offered: Every fall

This course is a problem-solving seminar intended for students planning to take the national math exam, the Putnam, this fall. You will work in groups to learn how to solve problems. It's a fun course whose final is the Putnam itself, but will not fufill any department requirements.

202A—Topology and Analysis

Instructor(s): Rieffel; Offered: Every fall

This is the first graduate course in analysis (though it's mainly taken by undergrads) and should not be taken lightly! Rieffel has taught this class since the 60s, and with him, the class will have a high attrition rate, will not follow a textbook, and will be considerably more difficult than in the past few years. However, unlike other graduate classes, there is a GSI. Contrary to rumor, he does in fact give multiple As per semester.

205—Functions of a Complex Variable

Instructor(s): Voiculescu; Offered: Sometimes

The graduate version of 185, but probably not worth taking. The last time Voiculescu taught 205, the class ended a month early.

214—Differentiable Manifolds

Instructor(s): Bamler; Offered: Sometimes, but it's often hijacked by Wodzicki, so if you want to take it take it now!

???

C218A—Probability Theory

Instructor(s): Pitman; Offered: Every fall

Also crosslisted as Stat C205A and that's what you have to enroll as on CalCentral. Pitman wrote the 134 textbook and enjoys teaching, but math majors often tend to blow off this class as easy -- it's still a graduate class and has the difficulty of one.

222A—Partial Differential Equations

Instructor(s): Tataru; Offered: Every fall

A class with engineers, but still lots of hard analysis. Tataru is a fun guy who wears the same shirt every day. He'll teach out of Evans' PDE book.

228A—Numerical PDEs

Instructor(s): Lin; Offered: Every fall?

A class full of engineers but still difficult proofs. Code in Julia. Lin is a good lecturer with hard homework.

249—Algebraic Combinatorics

Instructor(s): Serganova; Offered: Every fall?

This class is not easy, but is good to take with 250A, and is a good introduction to graduate courses. Serganova hasn't taught it recently, so topics will probably be different than usual.

250A—Groups, Rings, and Fields

Instructor(s): Nadler; Offered: Every fall

The first graduate algebra course (often taken by undergrads). Not to be taken lightly. Nadler prefers to talk about material from a high-level overview rather than give details.

We take full responsibility for our organization and this web site.

The background image was created by Prof. Semyon Dyatlov,
for use by the Harmonic Analysis and Differential Equations seminar.
It depicts the Bohr-Sommerfeld quantization condition for a one-dimensional potential well.
